questions.question: Which country is known as the Land of the Rising Sun?
questions.hint: An island nation in East Asia
questions.explanation: Japan is called the Land of the Rising Sun because it lies to the east of the Asian continent.

questions.question: Which language has the most native speakers worldwide?
questions.explanation: Mandarin Chinese has more native speakers than any other language.

questions.question: Which festival is known as the Festival of Lights in India?
questions.explanation: Diwali, or Deepavali, is known as the Festival of Lights and celebrates the victory of light over darkness.

questions.question: What is the tallest animal on Earth?
questions.hint: It has a very long neck
questions.explanation: The giraffe is the tallest animal, reaching heights over 5.5 meters.

questions.question: Which day is celebrated as World Environment Day?
questions.explanation: World Environment Day is celebrated every year on June 5 to encourage awareness for the environment.

questions.question: Which country is known as the Land of the Rising Sun?
questions.hint: An island nation in East Asia
questions.explanation: Japan is called the Land of the Rising Sun because it lies to the east of the Asian continent.

questions.question: Which language has the most native speakers worldwide?
questions.explanation: Mandarin Chinese has more native speakers than any other language.

questions.question: Which festival is known as the Festival of Lights in India?
questions.explanation: Diwali, or Deepavali, is known as the Festival of Lights and celebrates the victory of light over darkness.

questions.question: Which day is celebrated as World Environment Day?
questions.explanation: World Environment Day is celebrated every year on June 5 to encourage awareness for the environment.

questions.question: Which ocean is the largest?
questions.explanation: The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest ocean on Earth.

questions.question: Which country gifted the Statue of Liberty to the United States?
questions.hint: A European ally during the American Revolution
questions.explanation: France gifted the Statue of Liberty to the United States in 1886.

questions.question: Which element has the chemical symbol 'O'?
questions.explanation: The symbol 'O' stands for Oxygen in the periodic table.

questions.question: Which city is known as the Big Apple?
questions.explanation: New York City is famously nicknamed the Big Apple.

questions.question: Which instrument measures atmospheric pressure?
questions.explanation: A barometer measures atmospheric pressure, aiding weather prediction.

questions.question: Which planet is famous for its rings?
questions.explanation: Saturn’s ice and rock rings make it unique in the solar system.

questions.question: Which is the smallest country in the world?
questions.explanation: Vatican City covers about 0.49 km², the world’s smallest nation.

questions.question: Which continent has the most countries?
questions.explanation: Africa has 54 recognized countries, the highest of any continent.

questions.question: In which year did the Titanic sink?
questions.explanation: RMS Titanic sank on April 15, 1912 after hitting an iceberg.

questions.question: Which is the hardest natural substance on Earth?
questions.explanation: Diamond is the hardest natural material, rating 10 on Mohs scale.

questions.question: What is the capital city of Australia?
questions.explanation: Canberra is the capital city of Australia, chosen as a compromise between Sydney and Melbourne.

questions.question: What is the world’s longest river?
questions.explanation: The Nile River, at over 6,600 km, is often regarded as the longest river in the world.

questions.question: Which planet is known for having a Great Red Spot?
questions.explanation: Jupiter’s Great Red Spot is a giant storm larger than Earth that has persisted for centuries.

questions.question: Who wrote 'The Adventures of Tom Sawyer'?
questions.explanation: Mark Twain wrote this classic in 1876, set along the Mississippi River.

questions.question: What is the largest mammal on Earth?
questions.explanation: The Blue Whale can reach up to 30 meters in length and 180 metric tons.

questions.question: Which organ in the human body is responsible for pumping blood?
questions.explanation: The heart pumps oxygenated blood throughout the body.

questions.question: Which country invented paper?
questions.explanation: Paper was invented in ancient China during the Han Dynasty around 100 BC.

questions.question: What gas do humans exhale when they breathe out?
questions.explanation: Humans exhale carbon dioxide, a byproduct of respiration.

questions.question: Which famous scientist developed the theory of relativity?
questions.explanation: Albert Einstein’s theory of relativity revolutionized physics in the early 20th century.

questions.question: What is the main ingredient in guacamole?
questions.explanation: Guacamole is made primarily from mashed avocados, seasoned with lime and salt.

questions.question: Which continent is home to the Sahara Desert?
questions.explanation: The Sahara Desert is located in North Africa, spanning 11 countries.

questions.question: Who painted 'The Starry Night'?
questions.explanation: Vincent van Gogh painted 'The Starry Night' in 1889 while at a mental asylum in France.

questions.question: Which planet is known as the 'Morning Star' or 'Evening Star'?
questions.explanation: Venus is called both the Morning and Evening Star due to its brightness and orbit.

questions.question: What is the national currency of Japan?
questions.explanation: The Japanese Yen (JPY) is the official currency of Japan.

questions.question: Which blood type is known as the universal donor?
questions.explanation: O-negative blood can be safely transfused to patients of any blood group.

questions.question: Which element has the atomic number 1?
questions.explanation: Hydrogen, with one proton, is the first element on the periodic table.

questions.question: Who invented the telephone?
questions.explanation: Alexander Graham Bell patented the telephone in 1876.

questions.question: What is the national animal of India?
questions.explanation: The Bengal Tiger is India’s national animal.

questions.question: Which planet is known as the Blue Planet?
questions.explanation: Earth appears blue from space because of its oceans.

questions.question: Which is the largest island in the world?
questions.explanation: Greenland is the world’s largest island, covering over 2 million km².

questions.question: Which metal is liquid at room temperature?
questions.explanation: Mercury is the only metal that remains liquid at room temperature.

questions.question: What is the smallest prime number?
questions.explanation: 2 is the smallest and the only even prime number.

questions.question: Which ocean lies between Africa and Australia?
questions.explanation: The Indian Ocean is located between Africa, Asia, and Australia.

questions.question: Which organ purifies blood in the human body?
questions.explanation: The kidneys filter waste and excess water from the blood.

questions.question: What is the capital of Canada?
questions.explanation: Ottawa is the capital of Canada and home to Parliament Hill.

questions.question: Which vitamin is also known as ascorbic acid?
questions.explanation: Vitamin C, or ascorbic acid, helps repair tissues and boosts immunity.

questions.question: In which country is the Great Barrier Reef located?
questions.explanation: The Great Barrier Reef is the world’s largest coral reef system, located off Australia’s coast.

questions.question: Who discovered gravity?
questions.explanation: Isaac Newton formulated the law of universal gravitation in the 17th century.

questions.question: Which country has the most population in the world as of 2025?
questions.explanation: India surpassed China as the most populous country in 2023.

questions.question: Which city hosted the first modern Olympic Games?
questions.explanation: The first modern Olympic Games were held in Athens, Greece in 1896.

questions.question: Which continent is the driest on Earth?
questions.explanation: Antarctica receives less precipitation than any other continent.

questions.question: Which famous scientist proposed the three laws of motion?
questions.explanation: Sir Isaac Newton introduced the three laws of motion in his book Principia Mathematica.

questions.question: What is the largest internal organ in the human body?
questions.explanation: The liver is the largest internal organ, vital for detoxification and metabolism.

questions.question: Which city is known as the City of Canals?
questions.explanation: Venice, Italy, is built on 118 small islands connected by canals and bridges.

questions.question: Which instrument measures earthquakes?
questions.explanation: A seismograph detects and records the strength and duration of earthquakes.

questions.question: What is the smallest bone in the human body?
questions.explanation: The stapes bone in the middle ear is the smallest bone, just 3mm long.

questions.question: Which continent has no permanent human population?
questions.explanation: Antarctica has no permanent residents, only research stations.

questions.question: Who invented the light bulb?
questions.explanation: Thomas Edison patented the first practical light bulb in 1879.

questions.question: Which continent is the largest by area?
questions.explanation: Asia is the largest continent, covering about 30% of Earth’s land area.

questions.question: Which city is called the Silicon Valley of India?
questions.explanation: Bengaluru is known as the Silicon Valley of India due to its thriving IT industry.

questions.question: What is the largest desert in the world?
questions.explanation: The Antarctic desert is the world’s largest desert by area.

questions.question: Which chemical element is represented by 'Fe'?
questions.explanation: Fe is the chemical symbol for Iron.

questions.question: What is the largest planet in our solar system?
questions.explanation: Jupiter is the largest planet with a mass over 300 times Earth’s.

questions.question: Who was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize?
questions.explanation: Marie Curie was the first woman Nobel laureate, winning in 1903 and 1911.

questions.question: Which country is famous for inventing pizza?
questions.explanation: Pizza originated in Naples, Italy.

questions.question: What is the freezing point of water in Fahrenheit?
questions.explanation: Water freezes at 32°F or 0°C.

questions.question: Which is the fastest land animal?
questions.explanation: The cheetah can sprint at speeds over 100 km/h.

questions.question: What is the largest ocean on Earth?
questions.explanation: The Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean on Earth.

questions.question: What is the main language spoken in Brazil?
questions.explanation: Portuguese is the official language of Brazil.

questions.question: Which gas is essential for photosynthesis?
questions.hint: Absorbed by plants during the day
questions.explanation: Plants use carbon dioxide to produce glucose during photosynthesis.

questions.question: What planet is closest to the Sun?
questions.explanation: Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun.

questions.question: What part of the cell contains genetic material?
questions.explanation: The nucleus stores DNA, which contains genetic material.

questions.question: What is the powerhouse of the cell?
questions.explanation: Mitochondria generate energy in the form of ATP for cellular functions.

questions.question: Which vitamin is produced when the human body is exposed to sunlight?
questions.explanation: Sunlight triggers Vitamin D synthesis in the skin, essential for bone health.

questions.question: What planet is closest to the Sun?
questions.explanation: Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun.

questions.question: Which part of the cell contains genetic material?
questions.explanation: The nucleus stores DNA, which contains genetic material.

questions.question: What is the powerhouse of the cell?
questions.explanation: Mitochondria generate energy in the form of ATP for cellular functions.

questions.question: Which vitamin is produced when the human body is exposed to sunlight?
questions.explanation: Sunlight triggers Vitamin D synthesis in the skin, essential for bone health.

questions.question: What gas do plants absorb from the atmosphere?
questions.explanation: Plants absorb carbon dioxide and release oxygen during photosynthesis.

questions.question: What is the boiling point of water at sea level?
questions.explanation: At standard atmospheric pressure, water boils at 100°C.

questions.question: Which part of the human brain controls balance?
questions.hint: Located at the back of the brain
questions.explanation: The cerebellum regulates posture and coordination.

questions.question: What phenomenon causes the sky to appear blue?
questions.explanation: Rayleigh scattering of sunlight makes the sky look blue.

questions.question: Which organ in the human body filters blood?
questions.explanation: Kidneys remove waste and regulate fluid balance.

questions.question: What force keeps planets in orbit around the Sun?
questions.explanation: Gravity holds planets in elliptical orbits around the Sun.

questions.question: Who discovered penicillin?
questions.explanation: Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin in 1928, leading to antibiotics.

questions.question: Who was the first man to step on the Moon?
questions.explanation: Neil Armstrong became the first human to walk on the Moon in 1969.

questions.explanation: Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin in 1928, leading to antibiotics.

questions.explanation: Neil Armstrong became the first human to walk on the Moon in 1969.

questions.question: Who painted the Mona Lisa?
questions.explanation: Leonardo da Vinci painted the Mona Lisa in the early 1500s.

questions.question: Who was the British Prime Minister during WWII?
questions.hint: Known for 'We shall fight on the beaches' speech
questions.explanation: Winston Churchill led Britain to victory in WWII.

questions.question: In which year did India gain independence?
questions.explanation: India gained independence from Britain on August 15, 1947.

questions.question: What does 'AI' stand for in computing?
questions.explanation: AI stands for Artificial Intelligence, enabling machines to mimic human intelligence.

questions.question: Which programming language is primarily used for Android app development?
questions.explanation: Kotlin is officially supported by Google for Android development.

questions.explanation: AI stands for Artificial Intelligence, enabling machines to mimic human intelligence.

questions.question: Which programming language is primarily used for Android app development?
questions.explanation: Kotlin is officially supported by Google for Android development.

questions.question: What does 'HTTP' stand for?
questions.explanation: HTTP is the foundation of data communication on the Web.

questions.question: Which company developed Windows OS?
questions.explanation: Microsoft created Windows in 1985 as its flagship operating system.

questions.question: What does 'GPU' stand for?
questions.explanation: GPU stands for Graphics Processing Unit, handling image rendering tasks.

questions.question: Which country has won the most FIFA World Cups?
questions.explanation: Brazil has won 5 FIFA World Cups, the most of any nation.

questions.question: In which sport is the term 'birdie' used?
questions.explanation: In golf, a 'birdie' means completing a hole one stroke under par.

questions.explanation: Brazil has won 5 FIFA World Cups, the most of any nation.

questions.explanation: In golf, a 'birdie' means completing a hole one stroke under par.

questions.question: In tennis, what term means a score of zero?
questions.explanation: 'Love' is used for zero points in tennis scoring.

questions.question: Which sport uses a puck?
questions.explanation: Ice Hockey is played with a rubber puck on ice.

questions.question: Who has won the most Olympic gold medals ever?
questions.explanation: Swimmer Michael Phelps has won 23 Olympic gold medals.

questions.question: What does 'NP' stand for in computer science?
questions.explanation: NP refers to problems verifiable in polynomial time by a nondeterministic Turing machine.

questions.question: What is Schrödinger’s cat thought experiment meant to illustrate?
questions.hint: Involves a cat that is both alive and dead
questions.explanation: It demonstrates the paradox of quantum superposition applied to macroscopic systems.

questions.question: What is the Big O notation for binary search?
questions.explanation: Binary search has O(log n) time complexity in average and worst cases.

questions.question: What fundamental particle mediates the electromagnetic force?
questions.explanation: The photon is the quantum of the electromagnetic field.
